title: Lazio Healthcare — Hospitals, Insurance & Medical Guide
content:
Healthcare in Lazio is characterized by a well-organized and comprehensive system, with a wide range of public and private healthcare facilities, providing high-quality medical care to its residents and visitors.

[FACTBOX]
Healthcare System: Universal
Quality Rating: 4/5
Emergency Number: 118
Hospital Standard: Excellent
Insurance Required: recommended
Pharmacy Access: widespread
[/FACTBOX]

[SECTION] Healthcare Overview [/SECTION]
The healthcare system in Lazio, as part of Italy, is based on a universal model, providing comprehensive coverage to all citizens and residents. The system is divided into public and private sectors, with the public sector being the primary provider of healthcare services. The quality of care in Lazio is generally high, with well-equipped hospitals and skilled medical professionals. However, as with any healthcare system, there may be variations in the quality of care between urban and rural areas, with urban areas tend to have more advanced facilities and specialized services. The public healthcare system in Lazio is funded through a combination of government funding and patient contributions, making it accessible to all, regardless of income level.

The public healthcare system in Lazio is organized into local health authorities, known as **ASL** (Azienda Sanitaria Locale), which are responsible for providing healthcare services to the local population. These authorities manage a network of hospitals, clinics, and other healthcare facilities, and provide a range of services, including primary care, specialist care, and emergency services. In addition to the public sector, there are also many private healthcare providers in Lazio, offering a range of services, from primary care to specialized treatments.

The quality of care in Lazio is generally high, with many hospitals and clinics equipped with modern medical technology and staffed by skilled medical professionals. However, as with any healthcare system, there may be waiting times for non-emergency procedures, and some services may require a **prescription** or **referral** from a primary care physician. Overall, the healthcare system in Lazio provides comprehensive and high-quality care to its residents and visitors.

[SECTION] Health Insurance [/SECTION]
- **Private health insurance** is recommended for visitors and expats, as it provides access to private healthcare facilities and can help reduce waiting times for non-emergency procedures.
- **Public health insurance** is available to residents and citizens, and provides comprehensive coverage for medical services, including doctor visits, hospital stays, and prescriptions.
- **Supplementary insurance** is available to supplement public health insurance, and can provide additional coverage for services such as dental care, optical care, and alternative therapies.
- **Expats** may be eligible for public health insurance if they are employed or self-employed in Italy, or if they have a **residence permit**.
- **Costs** for health insurance vary depending on the provider and the level of coverage, but can range from a few hundred to several thousand euros per year.
- **Local insurance options** are available, including **INPS** (Istituto Nazionale della Previdenza Sociale) and **INAIL** (Istituto Nazionale per l'Assicurazione contro gli Infortuni sul Lavoro), which provide public health insurance and workers' compensation insurance, respectively.

[SECTION] Pharmacies & Medications [/SECTION]
- **Prescription medications** are widely available in Lazio, and can be obtained from pharmacies with a **prescription** from a licensed physician.
- **Over-the-counter medications** are also widely available, and can be purchased from pharmacies without a prescription.
- **Common brands** of medications are available, including international brands and generic equivalents.
- **Costs** for medications vary depending on the type and brand, but are generally lower than in other European countries.
- **Pharmacy access** is widespread, with many pharmacies located throughout urban and rural areas, and many pharmacies open late or 24 hours a day.

[SECTION] Vaccinations & Health Risks [/SECTION]
- **Required vaccinations** for travel to Lazio include **hepatitis A** and **hepatitis B**, as well as **tetanus** and **diphtheria**.
- **Recommended vaccinations** include **influenza**, **pneumococcal**, and **meningococcal**.
- **Endemic diseases** in Lazio include **Lyme disease** and **leishmaniasis**, which are transmitted through tick and sandfly bites, respectively.
- **Water safety** is generally good in Lazio, but visitors should take precautions when swimming in natural bodies of water, such as lakes and rivers.
- **Food safety** is also generally good in Lazio, but visitors should take precautions when eating undercooked meat, seafood, and eggs.
- **Sun protection** is recommended, as the sun can be strong in Lazio, particularly during the summer months.

[SECTION] Medical Tourism [/SECTION]
- **Popular procedures** for medical tourism in Lazio include **cosmetic surgery**, **dentistry**, and **fertility treatments**.
- **Accredited hospitals** in Lazio include the **Policlinico Umberto I** and the **Ospedale San Giovanni**, which offer a range of medical services to international patients.
- **Cost savings** can be significant for medical tourists, with prices for procedures often lower than in other European countries.
- **Language support** is available at many hospitals and clinics, with many medical professionals speaking **English** and other languages.

[SECTION] Emergency Procedures [/SECTION]
- **Emergency services** are available 24 hours a day, and can be accessed by calling **118** or visiting the emergency department of a hospital.
- **Ambulance reliability** is generally good, with ambulances equipped with modern medical technology and staffed by trained paramedics.
- **Nearest hospitals** can be found by searching online or contacting the local health authority, and many hospitals have **emergency departments** that are open 24 hours a day.
- **Insurance claims** can be complex, and visitors are recommended to contact their insurance provider for assistance with claims and billing.
- **Medical evacuation** may be necessary in some cases, and can be arranged through insurance providers or private companies.
